componenttext: Good afternoon, and welcome to the Digital Realty First Quarter 2016 Earnings Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] Please note this event is being recorded. I would now like to turn the conference over to John Stewart, Senior Vice President of Investor Relations. Please go ahead.

headline: Digital Realty Trust Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Amy. The speakers on today's call will be CEO, Bill Stein; and CFO, Andy Power. Chief Investment Officer, Scott Peterson; Chief Operating Officer, Jarrett Appleby; and SVP of Sales and Marketing, Matt Miszewski are also on the call and will be
componenttext: Thank you, Amy. The speakers on today's call will be CEO, Bill Stein; and CFO, Andy Power. Chief Investment Officer, Scott Peterson; Chief Operating Officer, Jarrett Appleby; and SVP of Sales and Marketing, Matt Miszewski are also on the call and will be available for Q&A. Management may make forward-looking statements related to future financial and other results, including 2016 guidance and the underlying assumptions. Forward-looking statements are based on current expectations, forecasts and assumptions and involve risks and uncertainties that could cause actual results to differ materially. For a further discussion of the risks and uncertainties related to our business, see our 2015 10-K and subsequent filings with the SEC. This call will contain non-GAAP financial information. Explanations and reconciliations to net income are included in the supplemental package furnished to the SEC and available by -- on our website. Management's prepared remarks will be followed by a Q&A session. Questions will be strictly limited to one plus a follow-up. If you have additional questions, please feel free to jump back in on the queue. And now, I'd like to turn the call over to Bill Stein.

headline: Digital Realty Trust Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, John. Good afternoon, and thank you all for joining us. We had another very productive first quarter, characterized by a solid execution against our strategic plan. In particular, we deliberately advanced our global footprint during the quarter
componenttext:
Thank you, John. Good afternoon, and thank you all for joining us. We had another very productive first quarter, characterized by a solid execution against our strategic plan. In particular, we deliberately advanced our global footprint during the quarter, the second of the 4 guiding principles that we laid out at our Investor Day last October and shown here on Page 2 of our earnings presentation. I'm very pleased to announce that we signed a multi-megawatt acre lease with a hyperscale cloud service provider in Osaka, fully pre-leasing phase 1 of our first project in Japan. We broke ground earlier this month and delivery is scheduled for the fourth quarter of next year. We also announced that we established a foothold in Germany with the acquisition of a land parcel in Frankfurt. We have begun the entitlement process, and we expect to be in a position to break ground later this year and deliver our first week in the second half of next year, subject to market demand. 
As you may recall, Germany and Japan have been our top 2 target markets, and we're very pleased that our progress during the first quarter, particularly in a manner that this consistent with our overarching objective of delivering superior risk-adjusted returns. We also delivered solid current period financial results. Andy will take you through the details in his prepared remarks, but the outperformance during the first quarter reflects consistent execution on the fourth objective here on Page 2, achieving operating efficiencies to accelerate growth in both cash flow and value per share.
As we've explained, we've made a conscious decision not to go up the stack or compete with our customers or offer managed services, nor do we intend to directly market to the broader array of enterprise customers and incur the overhead associated with building out the massive Salesforce necessary to target corporate enterprise directly. We aim instead to enable our partners to service enterprise customers upon the real estate foundation that we provide. 
Our partners and alliances program continue to build momentum during the first quarter, adding Sungard Availability services as a global partner. We are very excited about this partnership as it highlights our strategy of charging enterprise via our partners by combining our best-in-class infrastructure with our partners best-in-class services. We are in discussions with several other parties about joining our partners and alliances program, and we've added more resources to the team to support the growth of the program. 
In terms of capital recycling, during the first quarter, we closed on the previously announced sale of the former Solyndra facility in Fremont, California, to a core real estate institutional investor for $37.5 million or $108 per square foot at a 7.2% cap rate on our 2016 contractual cash NOI. We are still under contract on a national for property data center portfolio that we mentioned on our last earnings call and at our Investor Day. Due diligence is underway, and we expect to close within the next several months.
Let's now turn to market fundamentals. As you can see from the charts on Page 3, current construction activity, represented by the green bars, is most prevalent in Chicago, Dallas and Northern Virginia. Given the sector's recent history, any uptick in supply bears watching carefully. However, absolute levels of supply should also be considered in context, which we provide here on Page 4. First of all, current construction pipelines are generally concentrated in top-tier national markets with high visibility on demand and pre-leasing levels are healthy. In addition, market vacancy rates within these markets are in the single digits, and our own portfolios in these same markets are likewise north of 90% lease. These markets have also been characterized by robust levels of leasing activity. And in each case, the level of 2015 absorption represents a multiple of 2 to 3 times the level of current supply. Within the context of our own portfolio, we have delivered 38 megawatts of new product into these 3 markets over the last 12 months, and our deliveries were over 94% leased on average. We would expect a similar level of leasing on our current crop of property development projects upon delivery.
And now let's turn to the macro environment on Page 5. Global economic growth has stabilized somewhat over the last 90 days although the rate of growth still remain subdued. Growth of total IT spending is likewise lackluster. As I've said before, data center demand is not directly linked to job growth, household formation or the price of oil, and even the growth of total IT spending paints an incomplete picture. We have a good fortune to be levered to a subset of secular demand drivers that are both somewhat independent from and growing much faster than the broader economy, as well as the broader IT industry. Current industry trends are very favorable to our core strategy. Rather than spending more, CIOs, chief information officers, are looking to stress their IT dollar further. Narrowing the focus to core competencies is the order of the day, and outsourcing the corporate IT function is being embraced as the more efficient model. The rapid growth of cloud adoption is reflection of these same trends. IDC estimates that by 2018, 65% of companies IT assets are expected to be located off-site in colocation, hosting and cloud data centers, while 1/3 of IT staff are expected to be employees of third-party service providers. Similarly, IDC predicts that more than 80% of enterprise IT organizations will commit to a hybrid cloud architectures by 2017. These hybrid architectures require a colocation presence as well as close proximity to multiple clouds. Along with our partners, we provide the trusted real estate foundation for these deployments. 
The major cloud service providers are rapidly building out their compute note footprint to meet this demand. With our global foundation of data center solutions, we are uniquely positioned to support this rapid growth as we are one of the very few providers with the ability to meet these large scale requirements on a global basis. And now I'd like to turn the call over to Andy to take you through our financial results.

headline: Digital Realty Trust Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Bill. Let's begin with an update on Telx here on Page 7. Telx generated $92 million of revenue during the first quarter, representing 10% growth  year-over-year. Revenues remain split, roughly 50-50 between colocation and interconnection. From
componenttext:
Thank you, Bill. Let's begin with an update on Telx here on Page 7. Telx generated $92 million of revenue during the first quarter, representing 10% growth  year-over-year. Revenues remain split, roughly 50-50 between colocation and interconnection. From its existing 20 locations and prior to expense synergies, Telx generated $38 million of cash EBITDA during the first quarter.
Telx continues to perform at or slightly better than plan on all fronts, and we remain on track to meet or exceed our underwriting targets. Over the past 90 days, the Telx team has been focused on a few key areas within the business. First is our customers, where we continue to grow and expand our key communities and verticals within our Internet Gateways. Second is cash flow where we have been focused on the development of our commercial management team to drive additional revenue. Third is systems. We are in the process of integrating systems between the 2 organizations which will include a combined customer portal. 
With respect to expanding our customer base and nurturing our colocation ecosystem, we have emphasize the continued development of target verticals and communities. During the first quarter, Telx added 35 new logos, a 30% uptick from the number of new logos added during the prior quarter. In addition to our focus on cloud service providers, we continue to see growth within our Internet Gateways in areas such as content, wireless and mobility services, undersea cable systems and many other vertical that drive connectivity growth. We have been successful in enhancing the appeal of our facilities by attracting numerous undersea cable systems. We announced the faster and [indiscernible] cable systems last year, and we plan to announce the signing of an additional undersea cable system within the next few weeks. We expect these efforts to continue to drive interconnection growth and offer customer base continue diversity and global connectivity options from within our facilities. 
With regard to the commercial management team, we have been very focused on revenue optimization to ensure accurate and timely billing and collection for space, power and connectivity within our facilities. This team has increased its focus on pursuing contractual annual REIT increases from our colocation customers while within their term, and we're working to consolidate legacy contractual agreements across our data center platform. 
With respect to systems, we identified our target IT architecture during the first quarter, and we are working quickly to consolidate these platforms. But we want to be sure that we deliver seamless customer experience before introducing additional complexity to our systems' landscape. We're making solid headway, and we expect this effort to continue as a top priority for the next few quarters. 
Finally, we recognize that our customer portal is 1 of the top drivers for improving customer satisfaction to our 1,600 customers. Telx introduced a world-class portal over 4 years ago to improve service capabilities to drive revenue, as well as functionality line customers to easily discover and connect to each other. We believe the self-service storefront capabilities in this system marketplace will help retain existing customers while growing the installed base with new entrants seeking to benefit from this developing ecosystem. We hope many of you will be able to attend marketplace live in New York City on September 22, where we plan to unveil several new additions and upgrades to the portal. In summary, while integration is still underway, we remain pleased with the progress and the performance to date.
Let's turn to our leasing activity on Page 8. We signed new leases, totaling $39 million of annualized GAAP rent during the first quarter, including a $6 million contribution from Telx for space and power. In addition, Telx contributed $8 million of annualized interconnection revenue bookings during the first quarter. 
Social, mobile, analytics, cloud and content accounted for approximately 80% of our leases signed during the quarter. And over 90% was repeat business with existing customers. The combined organization added a total of 41 new logos during the quarter.
The weighted average lag between signings and commencements was 8 months, driven primarily by the pre-lease Bill alluded to on our first project in Japan. We broke ground earlier this month and delivery is scheduled for next fall. Excluding the new build in Osaka, the lag between signings and commencements was 5 months, in line with our customary activity. As shown on Page 9, the backlog of leases signed but not yet commenced now stands at $90 million, the bulk of which is expected to commence this year. I would also like to point out here on Page 9 that in response to feedback from analysts and investors, we have provided a bridge to reconcile the prior quarter backlog to the $90 million current backlog.
Turning to renewal leasing activity on Page 10. We signed a little over $50 million of leasing renewals during the first quarter, in addition to new leases signed up. The average cash releasing spread was up 2% with a positive cash mark-to-market on turnkey and colocation renewals laid down a bit by a modest cash rental down on a relatively small sample size and the PBB renewals during the first quarter. 
As mentioned on previous calls, we do still have several remaining above-market scale leases, notably in Phoenix and in pockets of our East Coast portfolio, and we expect a couple of those to hit during the second quarter, which will likely result in a cash rent roll down during the second quarter. We expect to see positive cash flow releasing spread in the second half of the year. And for the full year, we still expect to be roughly flat on a cash basis and up in the high single digits on a GAAP basis. In general, we expect to see continued improvement in the mark-to-market across our portfolio, driven by modest market rent growth and a steady progress we have made cycling through peak vintage lease expirations.
Turning to our financial results on Page 11. We reported 1Q '16 core FFO per share of $1.42, $0.07 ahead of consensus estimates. Several initiatives we outlined in our Investor Day designed to drive additional cash flow from our properties and leverage our scale to achieving operating efficiencies are beginning to bear fruit. And the upside during the first quarter was driven by operating outperformance as well as interest savings. Specifically, one penny was due to outperformance from the Digital Realty portfolio, another penny was due to the Telx outperformance during the quarter. $0.02 were due to lower-than-expected overhead. And lastly, interest expense was $0.03 lower than expected do primarily to the timing and the pricing achieved on the term loan in January and the eurobond in April. 
AFFO per share was likewise well ahead of plan, partially driven by the BFFO line, along with a further reduction straight-line rental revenue. Recurring FX was also down significantly, although this largely reflects seasonally lighter CapEx spending, and we do expect recurring CapEx to pick up over the course of the year.
As you may have seen from the press release, we raised our core FFO per share guidance from $5.45 to $5.60 to a range of $5.55 to $5.65. We raised the projected EBITDA margin by 50 basis points, again reflecting the benefit of the operating efficiencies we've been able to achieve. This is reflected on the G&A line as well as the property level, and we raised both ends of the range for our 2016 same-capital cash NOI growth guidance by 100 basis points from 0 to 3% to 1% to 4%, or roughly 2% to 5% on a constant-currency basis. 
Finally, interest rates on the term loan as well as the Eurobond both came in tighter than expected. And we have revised our financings assumption to reflect actual capital raise to date. The forecast does still include a potential $300 million to $400 million bond offering later this year. 
FX represented a roughly 100 to 150 basis point drag on the year-to-year growth on our reported results to the top to the bottom line as shown here on Page 12. Although foreign currency headwinds are abating somewhat, the U.K. represents our largest concentration outside the U.S. The dollar is currently strong compared to 2015 average sterling exchange rate and our 2016 outlook contemplates a continued drag of similar magnitude for the remainder of the year. 
I would like to remind you that we manage currency risks by issuing a locally-denominated debt to act as a natural hedge. So only our net assets within a given region are exposed to currency risk from an economic perspective. I would also like to point out that we completed our inaugural eurobond offering in early April. We raised EUR 600 million, further enhancing our natural hedge and reducing our non-U.S. dollar nominated net asset exposure to less than 10%. 
Finally, I would like to point out that while our global footprint exposes us to currency translation exposure, it also enables us to satisfy data center requirements of strategic customers around the world, which we believe represents a key competitive advantage.
In terms of our first quarter operating performance, same-capital occupancy slipped 10 basis points sequentially, same-capital cash NOI was up 4.3% year-over-year. On a constant-currency basis, same-capital cash NOI would have been up approximately 5%. I would like to -- I would also like to remind everyone that our 2016 same-store presentation is somewhat theoretical, since we have elected to report same-capital results for 2016 as if our leases with Telx were still in place. Given the Telx was previously a customer in 11 of our properties, most of which are Internet Gateways that comprise a huge chunk of our stabilized portfolio.
Let's turn to balance sheet on Page 13. As previously announced, we closed on the refinancing of our global senior unsecured credit facilities in January. In the process, we were able to tighten pricing by 10 basis points, extend the maturity date by more than 2 years and upsize the term loan facilities by $550 million, including $300 million of 7-year paper. As you can see from the chart on Page 13, the refinancing effectively clears the left-hand side of the maturity schedule. We have just under $300 million or less than 5% of total debt coming due before 2020. 
Subsequent to the end of the quarter, we priced our inaugural $600 million eurobond offering at a 2.625% coupon in early April. Just to be clear, since it may not have been for everyone, 2 5/8 with the all-in pricing, not just the spread. We were fortunate to price within 1 basis point of the all-time low in the benchmark 8-year mid-swap rate. And needless to say, we were pleased with the execution. We presented the pro forma impact of the eurobond issuance here on Page 14 of the presentation. And as you can see, the 8-year term fit perfectly in the 1 open [indiscernible] in our debt maturity ladder in 2024. 
Proceeds were used to refinance and term out borrowings on the line of credit, and the current balance on the line is less than $100 million with over $1.9 billion of availability. Floating rate debt now represents less than 10% of total debt outstanding.
In addition, as you can see from the colo box in the left-hand side of the chart, the weighted average debt maturity is now 6.8 years. 2, full years longer than a weighted average maturity as at the end of 1Q '15. Terming out over $1 billion of long-term debt does have a dilutive earnings impact, but we believe locking in long-term fixed rate financing from a new source of institutional capital providers is proven financial management. Consistent with our financial strategy, we are maintaining our balance sheet well positioned for new investment opportunities. This concludes our prepared remarks. And now we will be pleased to take your questions. Amy, would you please begin the Q&A session?

componenttext: First question was regarding the hyperscale cloud lease. I guess, you announced one that sounds like will commence some time later next year in Osaka. But just curious overall, the trend has been for pretty significant leasing across the board amongst your peers, you guys had an above average quarter relative to the last couple. But this is not -- haven't -- we haven't really seen a spike in overall leasing volume from you guys, yet you do have some availability and obviously a sizable global footprint. Can you talk about what you're seeing on a hyperscale cloud requirements side if there's more to do there or what have you?

headline: Digital Realty Trust Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Hey, Jordan. It's Matt. Thanks for the question. Now with regard to the quarter, of course, my team -- my global team is very pleased with our most recent quarter coming in around a $40 million design is kind of as you've mentioned, not to mentioned he wi
componenttext: Hey, Jordan. It's Matt. Thanks for the question. Now with regard to the quarter, of course, my team -- my global team is very pleased with our most recent quarter coming in around a $40 million design is kind of as you've mentioned, not to mentioned he will come revenue contribution of $8 million coming from our interconnection business. It is important to remember when we talked about the current leasing environment out in the industry that we aren't really new to this hyperscale cloud game. In fact, while we talked in the opening remarks about the 1 deal that was in Anchor in Osaka, we've done more deals in Q1 with hyperscale cloud providers as well. And we've been addressing this demand for more than a few years now successfully. And during that time period, as well as Q1, we captured multiple multi-megawatt requirements from various, not just 1, but various hyperscale cloud service providers around the world. And from our perspective, these requirements may be a little less than conspicuous in our quarterly leasing results given the diverse nature of what has become a consistent $30 million to $40 million contribution of quarter leasing activities. So for instance, this quarter, Jordan, about 30% of our signings came from the top 3 cloud service providers. About an additional 20% came from targeted cloud providers outside of those top 3. And then, a bit more than 30% came from our diversified stack of a social, mobile, analytics, cloud and content comps. It's important that we keep in mind that in addition to our quarterly when here in the U.S., we're also successfully landing requirements in our target global markets, not simply in Japan, in London as well, which tend to be comparatively bluer oceans, where our publicly traded domestic data center peers may not have a dominant presence. And the final piece of my response would be that my team, as you know remains intently committed to strong leasing fundamentals as beneficial to shareholders while we keep our eye on driving this growing hyperscale demand.

headline: Digital Realty Trust Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, that's helpful. And just as a follow-up, in terms of capital, I see leverage ticking up to 5.3x debt to EBITDA. And at the same time, we've seen some of your smaller peers cap [ph] the equity market, given sort of the performance in stocks and sort
componenttext: Okay, that's helpful. And just as a follow-up, in terms of capital, I see leverage ticking up to 5.3x debt to EBITDA. And at the same time, we've seen some of your smaller peers cap [ph] the equity market, given sort of the performance in stocks and sort of the strong fundamentals seen in your sectors. headline: Digital Realty Trust Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Hey, Jordan. It's Andy. So the tick up was 5.2x to 5.3x, but I think I get the gist of your question. So our funding strategy for the year remains the same. The base case is to fund our development with our retained capital proceeds from our asset sales a
componenttext: Hey, Jordan. It's Andy. So the tick up was 5.2x to 5.3x, but I think I get the gist of your question. So our funding strategy for the year remains the same. The base case is to fund our development with our retained capital proceeds from our asset sales and our debt raises, which are largely finished now. With that funding strategy, we see our leverage throughout each and every quarter of the year between that target of 5 to 5.5x net debt to EBITDA, so right at our target levels. In addition, right now, we have less than $100 million on the revolver. Now the facts changed. And if we see an opportunistic investment opportunity, we'll certainly look to issue equity similar to what we have done in the past.

componenttext: Thanks, Jonathan, for the question. With regards to both Japan and Frankfurt, as you know, we've got an EMEA team as well as an Asia Pacific team. And in Asia Pacific, as we announced last quarter, we brought on an a new Managing Director in Ted Hagazi [ph] to be able to help us to make sure that we hit that market extremely well. His background in Japan will, coincidentally or maybe not so coincidentally, help us out a great deal in making sure that the Asia Pacific sales team has a head start in being able to hit the demand in Japan. Similarly, in Europe, Wendy Will is our Managing Director for the immediate team and has the ability to help that team hit new markets, including the new markets that we see in Germany. We've got a sufficient staff and leadership in place in EMEA from a sales and sales operations perspective to be able to hit that demand quickly, and we've been monitoring the demand pipeline for Germany for quite some time. And we've got a significant built up pipeline that we are ready to clear.

componenttextpreview: Thanks. Great question. And there was a good deal of leasing, in particular, in 1 of our markets in the Central Region, 1 of our great campuses in Chicago, where it was powered -- we'll call it power enhancement, but basically driving additional density i
componenttext: Thanks. Great question. And there was a good deal of leasing, in particular, in 1 of our markets in the Central Region, 1 of our great campuses in Chicago, where it was powered -- we'll call it power enhancement, but basically driving additional density into the floor space that's already taken by individual customer. We think of these are fantastic wins from us. From an economic perspective, they're fantastic for us. From a power perspective, they're very good for us. Even from a relationship with utilities that we do business with, it increases the utilization of the power that's committed by those individual utility. And we do see density place continue to play out throughout our portfolio, where we can increase the stickiness of those individual customers in our facilities, by bringing them additional power. It's also a great signal that our customers are doing well. In this case, these customers are doing extremely well in it's taking power at a rate that we didn't anticipate, but it actually ended up helping a great deal.

componenttext: Sure. So when, the guidance yields are roughly 10.5% to 12.5%. It's really just a function of when you bring on new projects, how these stay and initial yields are a little lower or if it depends in the market. But we -- all in all, we see the yields of of still within our bogey [ph]. In terms of the total size of the pipeline, I -- we haven't seen anything right now that's going to a have a massive shift or increase in our pipeline. We still have -- that's a consistent amount of annual spend. The 1 point I would is clarify though while we have $540 million of remaining spend for these projects, that the some of these are preleased, over half of that and some of it is speculative. We're actually only contractually committed to finish roughly $380 million of that. So if the music did stop and we -- there was oversupply to any market that would represent like 0.3 turns of debt-to-EBITDA so our balance sheet leverage will still be in check. And as I mentioned before, we have $1.9 billion of availability on our revolver. So no crisis would ensue.

headline: Digital Realty Trust Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: So I just want to follow up on the hyperscale lease that you guys signed. Just curious what these conversations are like with these cloud guys. Obviously, you and your peers have been signing a lot of leases. So I'm just curious when you sit down and meet
componenttext: So I just want to follow up on the hyperscale lease that you guys signed. Just curious what these conversations are like with these cloud guys. Obviously, you and your peers have been signing a lot of leases. So I'm just curious when you sit down and meet with them, are they -- is there so much the demand that they're just scrambling to try and go much space as they can, or are these more strategic expansion, just trying to get into new markets and the business will grow into it? Just trying to get a sense of whether this is just one big wave or whether this is just to meet the kind of demand out there has going to continue?

headline: Digital Realty Trust Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. I think it's a little bit of a combination of both of those. And it depends on which 1 of the hyperscale providers we're talking to and how far along they are in their planned execution. And then, what type of visibility day have into their own deman
componenttext: Yes. I think it's a little bit of a combination of both of those. And it depends on which 1 of the hyperscale providers we're talking to and how far along they are in their planned execution. And then, what type of visibility day have into their own demand. And that really is a little bit different from, I would say, cloud service provider to a cloud service provider. A number of them have had advanced plans and there's meet with advance planning. A number of them have seen a radical shift in terms of the demand coming to them. And so in their hot markets, which happen to line up with some of our hot markets, they want to occupy as much space and power as they can because they know that they will burn it to utilize it. So it really does depend. I would say about half and half amongst cloud providers in terms of the current large amount of deployments that they're through to hit their current set of demand, but also to make sure that they understand he can cover demand that they historically might have missed because they didn't have inventory in the market.

headline: Digital Realty Trust Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: And I guess as my follow up. And in terms of the decision there making to lease space rather than build up themselves. Obviously, some of these guys like Amazon and Microsoft have a scale to do it themselves and they do. Is there -- is the reason that the
componenttext: And I guess as my follow up. And in terms of the decision there making to lease space rather than build up themselves. Obviously, some of these guys like Amazon and Microsoft have a scale to do it themselves and they do. Is there -- is the reason that they're doing more leasing because, just because they need to space and you guys already have an entitled space is easier? Or is there a strategic reason that they want to be in a third party release facility?

headline: Digital Realty Trust Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. I mean, there's a few of them. And you can see that a number of these folks have actually done some of the builds themselves in the past. I would say part of that past activity was because of slow changes to the multi-tenant data center environment t
componenttext: Yes. I mean, there's a few of them. And you can see that a number of these folks have actually done some of the builds themselves in the past. I would say part of that past activity was because of slow changes to the multi-tenant data center environment to adjust to their needs. I think, over the past 6 months, they have been satisfied that multi-tenant data center providers like us, have the ability to hit their needs and their capital is better spent, focusing on the strategic imperative that they have in front of them. So while they might have hit a gap in their own will build, they all have sort of come to the realization that leasing is something that they need to, not just explore, but execute on. Jarrett?

headline: Digital Realty Trust Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: And just to build on the architectural trends, we've talked about all the cloud and hybrid cloud. It's really important for these cloud service providers have colocation and interconnection on the campus as well. So I think this is a trend that you're see
componenttext: And just to build on the architectural trends, we've talked about all the cloud and hybrid cloud. It's really important for these cloud service providers have colocation and interconnection on the campus as well. So I think this is a trend that you're seeing a value proposition that we can that day land our compute engine and support the cloud, but then enterprises and partners can deliver private cloud and connectivity right next door, and that's a great value prop.

componenttext: This is Scott. Good question, Matt. Japan, that represents Phase 1 if it's 100% prerelease with that anchor tenant. So future development there would be subject to additional market demand. Germany, we want to develop in conjunction with market demand although there's a pretty strong demonstrated pipeline of demand in that market. So I think we would feel a little more comfortable pushing forward a little more aggressively there.

componenttext: Yes. So as you know, there's a different set of demand drivers inside that European market. And you certainly nail it on their head. In the places where we see the most amount of demand, we found ourselves are tough enough inventory to satisfy that demand. So in particular, in Amsterdam and in London, where we are currently swinging shovels or swinging hammers or a combination of both, I don't know if it's just a swinging shovel, but it depends on what you're doing I guess. But we are satisfying that probably in London and Amsterdam. Same thing in Frankfurt, where did have demonstrated demand, but obviously we didn't have a presence there as well.

headline: Digital Realty Trust Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: And Matt, this is Andy speaking. And so the underwriting and returns piece of the equation really mostly applies to bringing on new supply where we have to build either by land or build from the ground up. Every -- we've got a giant portfolio with pockets
componenttext: And Matt, this is Andy speaking. And so the underwriting and returns piece of the equation really mostly applies to bringing on new supply where we have to build either by land or build from the ground up. Every -- we've got a giant portfolio with pockets of agency throughout different markets, where it's not whether the deal makes underwriting hurdle. It's about marketing, finding demand and landing in locations. So that's not all -- the underwriting is not always the governor for whether a lease land or not.

headline: Digital Realty Trust Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016

componenttext: Okay. And then, as a follow-up. Can you just give us some color on the 100 basis points increase in guidance for the same capital NOI. Is that being partially driven by the G&A improvement, and kind of how does that reconcile against the pretty stabilized -- the lower pretty stabilized yield? Is that factored in at all?

headline: Digital Realty Trust Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. So those are probably several separate parts of our P&L. So same-store capital, NOI is not in a really pick up new development contributions. Reasons for same-store or our view of increased occupancy in the same-store has really been the results in
componenttext: Sure. So those are probably several separate parts of our P&L. So same-store capital, NOI is not in a really pick up new development contributions. Reasons for same-store or our view of increased occupancy in the same-store has really been the results in the first quarter. And what we've seen going to the second quarter. I think that's both on the top line and the bottom line. You mentioned the bottom line, it's really on the -- on an NOI basis, it's better operations at the property level. So I think if you look through our P&L, especially in the same-store side of it, most of our expenses were flat or potentially down in some categories. So we're running the properties more efficiently. And then on the top line, we did have some mark-to-market outcomes that were a little bit better than we planned, which is driving some of the increase in the same-store cash NOI growth.

componenttext: If we switch back to the Japan lease for a second, if we just think about the timing there, where they're not going to be occupying until essentially I guess early '18 at this point, subject by your development schedule. How do you think about the capacity that they need, and can we balance that against your comments about not building spec there? headline: Digital Realty Trust Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. So hey, Manny [ph] In terms of just to clarify, actually I think that the Japan lease will commence in late 2017. But it's a good question in terms of is the demand that we're seeing, not just for that particular -- and I assume, your question applie
componenttext: Yes. So hey, Manny [ph] In terms of just to clarify, actually I think that the Japan lease will commence in late 2017. But it's a good question in terms of is the demand that we're seeing, not just for that particular -- and I assume, your question applies to just more than just the Japan deal and applies across the board with these types of deals that we're seeing. And how do the customers think about what their takes will be and how do we respond to those. We've got a really good process actually in place to understand the production capabilities that we have and how those production capabilities match up to what our customers really need. I'll talk about what our customers need, and I'll turn it over to Jarrett to talk about the production sizes and the production capabilities that we have. In terms of the way our customers look at this, they still sort of look at it as having a foot in each of these markets and each of these buildings, and each of these facilities that usually comes in the shape of at least 1, what we used to call POD, but 1 scale oriented POD. Sometimes 2 scale oriented-POD that we needed short quarter. One is generally the size that they need up-front, and they need to have visibility so that they're not then outgrow their needs and they're not going to outgrow the colo needs that they know their customers are going to need in the hybrid cloud environment. And I'll have Jarrett answer the rest of the question.

headline: Digital Realty Trust Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: And I think, Manny [ph], to build on what we just said. I think we talked about Investor Day, the new agile product that we're rolling out globally. Once we really designed 2 options, the powered dense option that you're starting to see and a base option,
componenttext: And I think, Manny [ph], to build on what we just said. I think we talked about Investor Day, the new agile product that we're rolling out globally. Once we really designed 2 options, the powered dense option that you're starting to see and a base option, which is the agility for the client. As well as once we get the shell up, we will then can deliver pods, as Matt was talking about, every 3 to 4 months. So that gives us a lot more agility as we see demand in that market. And so I think when you pair that, you can sell into a market and meet different customer needs on that time line.

headline: Digital Realty Trust Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: And maybe a question for Andy. So Andy, if I look at Slide 11 of the deck. I guess that's a a walk coming from consensus to actual. Maybe 2 questions related to that. If you were to make that left most column, not consensus but where your expectations wer
componenttext: And maybe a question for Andy. So Andy, if I look at Slide 11 of the deck. I guess that's a a walk coming from consensus to actual. Maybe 2 questions related to that. If you were to make that left most column, not consensus but where your expectations were, would the step sort of be the same, so did you outperform your own expectations as well? And then secondly, how much of this was a timing shift, and how much of it is going to impact the rest of the year and sort of more onetime in 1Q?

headline: Digital Realty Trust Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure, Many. This is Andy. I think that's your third question. We're going to give you a pass today, because we like you so much. So the 1 35 was roughly around our internal projections. So we're right in line, so we want to kind of try the step functions
componenttext: Sure, Many. This is Andy. I think that's your third question. We're going to give you a pass today, because we like you so much. So the 1 35 was roughly around our internal projections. So we're right in line, so we want to kind of try the step functions kind of mirror what our internal results look like. The -- I'd say most of these are flow through to the rest of the year. So the Digital Realty NOI, Telx EBITDA. G&A, there may be some timing elements to it as part of our non-comp related travel consulting fees like that. So if budget people exceeds budget in subsequent quarters essentially using budget used in the first quarter. And then the lower interest expense. I mean that's a product of 2 things. The timing and when we did our capital raises and actually our execution on the capital raises. The one thing I would caveat, it's not as simple as just taking the far right bar and times it by 4 to get our full year number. The -- we do have some items that will reduce that full year number and offset our increases in revenue. One of those is that portfolio of data centers that we have under contract and to sell, hopefully, the next month or so, that will obviously be diluted out of the gates when we sell $120-ish million of assets that are income-producing. And in the second item is we basically had a revolver balance at $600 million, $700 million for most of the quarter and then did a $600 million eurobond. Subsequent to quarter end and now the fixed rate 8-year piece of paper which is obviously good for the balance sheet locks in long-dated hedged debt that but is not as low as a floating rate revolver debt.

headline: Digital Realty Trust Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016

headline: Digital Realty Trust Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016

componenttext: So I guess I ask almost the same question last quarter, but I'm still a very interested in really understand about the progress, just keep getting another quarter under the belts of having both Telx and also the sort of large campus data centers, and the interplay there, particularly in driving the cloud enterprise ecosystem. So I'd love to get a little perspective on how that's coming along. And I guess as a say short of subquestion there, Jarrett give some good color I think in an earlier response about why the hyperscale guys are interested in your assets, given the ability to drive that connectivity there as well. But I'd be interested, I guess, sort of on the the opposite side as to hear about the enterprises coming in to connect with the scale cloud guys. And you did call out the $7.5 million of incremental interconnection fee that you were able book off of [indiscernible] quarter. And it would be good to get some perspective, I don't know whether it was in the fourth quarter or what it might have looked like a year ago. But is this a number that was in acceleration in line, et cetera?

headline: Digital Realty Trust Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Jefferson. This is Andy. I'll take the first part of that, and I'll open up to the team to answer. So the Telx update integration, what you call it. We make a very good progress as you can see from the numbers on the Investor Presentation. We're on track
componenttext: Jefferson. This is Andy. I'll take the first part of that, and I'll open up to the team to answer. So the Telx update integration, what you call it. We make a very good progress as you can see from the numbers on the Investor Presentation. We're on track and potentially exceeded our expectations from the initial underwriting. We -- as we previously mentioned on our prior call, about our investor community improving the Telx expansion on [indiscernible] campus. We have now started to be selectivity, and we should have the doors open there come September. I think you can expect some additional new market expansion to unfold throughout the remainder of the year. On the West Coast, well, I'd be fortunate enough to sign subsea cable, a which we think will enhance our Telx -- attractiveness of our Telx footprint and the entire footprint in the market. We're also looking -- we're expanding our footprint in Atlanta where we've been very successful in [indiscernible]. So so far so good as it relates to Telx. Just to jump around. But from interconnection revenue line item, we're tracking year-over-year on just that revenue component north of 10%, I think it was close to 11%. And then quarter-over-quarter, I think it's up about 2-ish percent just for interconnection revenue. And then, I'll turn it over to the team to answer, I think your middle question.

headline: Digital Realty Trust Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Jeff. Jonathan, whatever your name is today. Real quick on the first part of your question. Hopefully, to give you a little color on what Andy said and some pretty concrete examples of where we see the combination really coming together quite impressively
componenttext: Jeff. Jonathan, whatever your name is today. Real quick on the first part of your question. Hopefully, to give you a little color on what Andy said and some pretty concrete examples of where we see the combination really coming together quite impressively. We've been through a number of events where we bring both teams together to address customers. Start -- I'd would say it started very actively with PDC [ph]. We've got ITW [ph] coming up and we've been in a number of events in between. And what's interesting is the reaction from our customers has been absolutely fantastic. So not only have they thanked us for coming together for giving them in essence, one [indiscernible] for all of their scale colo cross connect and other services needs, but we've seen a number of them actually start to change their own individual organization structure to come to us in the same way that we're now coming to them all in 1. So we've seen -- and I've now seen this last week, the fourth large cloud service provider making decision to consolidate their network folks with their data center folks to make sure that they're coming to market the right way. So I don't know -- I'm not claiming of credit to that because of what we did, but I'm letting you know that it's landing pretty well, the Telx and large campus together. Let me get to the heart of what I think Andy turn it over to me for, which is the why hyperscale is coming into Digital Realty, in particular with our set of assets. There's a couple that Jarrett has talked about individually. One is first of all, we get hyperscale. We've been doing hyperscale before someone fully turned it hyperscale. We've been doing large deployment, and we figured out how to make a fairly profitable business out of it from the beginning. So these folks are comfortable that we know what we're doing, and we've got the size and scale, no pun intended, to have a good counterparty on the other side of the transaction for their large compute node need. But they also know that their customers need more than simply the ability to provide cloud services through 1 data center, 5 data centers throughout the world. They also need to have colocation availability so that those folks have the ability to land what they cannot put into public cloud, cannot maybe put into a private cloud and have to put into their enterprise class data center, and then they need connectivity to bring them all together. We just came from our final advisory board, and several of them came to us and said, "We love the idea that we can now get this at the 1 organization." They're looking for ease. They're looking to take the complexity out of the IP transactions that they have in front of them, and we're able to act as that vehicle that takes that complexity away. I would say in the future, we've had some future-oriented conversations about where they're taking the business into the future with their platforms as a service offerings, and they're very interested in being involved with the companies that has now 1,600 customers, many of them are IT service providers, many of them providing the service component that they're putting together into the applications delivering into the future, and they want to be able to offer that to their end customers. And Digital is uniquely situated to be able to provide that value proposition where nobody else can.

componenttext: Okay, that's helpful. The second question comes under development pipelines. It comes from Page 34 of your supplemental. Again, the development yield, I guess on the current pipeline, is 10.3%. Last quarter, it was 11.2%. And I recognize, I think part of that decline, I'm guessing as you've got Osaka in there for the first time, and assume that's a lower yield just given interest rates in Japan, you're willing to develop that lower yield. I'll be looking for you to A, confirm that.  And then but B, when I look at the development yields in U.S. and Europe, those also came down a little bit. So I'm just curious, there's some commentary on the development yield. And then the last part of development question, the cost went up $10 million on Singapore and you delay it a quarter. If you can just comment on that one?

headline: Digital Realty Trust Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016

componenttext: Hey, Ross. This is Andy. So you're right, I can -- the main drivers in Osaka bringing down the yield. The other element, I would say, is that if you bridge between the last quarter in this quarter, and I think we highlighted in 1 of our slides. We did deliver, I believe 13.2 megawatts across Dallas, Chicago, Northern Virginia that was pretty well leased at an attractive yield, and we've rolled on some of the -- really the last phases of Northern Virginia project before we may have to move on the next added some other new phases in Chicago and Dallas, which obviously are less well leased, and we include our underwriting estimate in this table until leasing actually comes in. And we typically outperform our underwriting. And when we hit the leasing, you'll potentially see these yields go up. And then the other question was the Singapore timing and costs. Maybe FX rates will be a driver there. I think we're at budget or under budget there. I know that the ribbon-cutting ceremony in May or June, right?

componenttext: Sure, Jordan. So as a reminder, that top row was our initial underwriting when we announced the transaction back in the middle of July. The key and repeated number is $148-plus million of our cash EBITDA. We are, I would say, ahead of plan for just the first quarter. Some of that beat [ph] was on the expense side that may have been a little bit seasonal and timing-related. The timing for the annual SKO or sales kickoff in marketing the sales initiatives around that event actually moved. Last year, it was in the first quarter. We actually pull it forward and did it in December this past year. So again, that's probably not a number you can necessarily just annualized to get the run rate. We are ramping additional resources on the sales and marketing front there. But all in all, we're making good progress on the revenue and the EBITDA line item and feel like we're on track to meet or exceed our underwriting estimates.

componenttext: Okay. And then separately, just in the partners and alliances program, can you maybe just give us a sense, how do you get -- how are you confident in that program and the potential of that program, or what gives you confidence, should I say, as opposed to the other route of sort of bolstering or building out the sales platform like some of your competitors have?

headline: Digital Realty Trust Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Jordan. First of all, Bill and Andy won't let me build-out sales force to address that potential demand. And I am happily compliant with not building it out. And just to be clear, right, it was clearly a differentiator between us and other folks i
componenttext: Thanks, Jordan. First of all, Bill and Andy won't let me build-out sales force to address that potential demand. And I am happily compliant with not building it out. And just to be clear, right, it was clearly a differentiator between us and other folks in this industry. So it was not that we didn't have some trepidation in making the decision to address a large segment of the potential revenue in what amounts to an entirely different way for us as a company. So that was not without personal risk on my side, but also just a little bit of risk on our side. But it's a great question. How do we feel confident that it's going 2 main components make me feel confident? And the first, it always starts with our customers. I think during last earnings call, we have just come from a meeting with 1 of our top 5 customers, and the reception from us having a conversation with those C level of folks and talking to them about not competing with them and asking for their support and signing up for the partnership program and being actively involved in helping us pass lead back and forth and being through partners gives me a great deal of confidence. And then secondly, nothing brings confidence like pipeline, and especially in my particular world. And so the guys this year, in the first quarter, have already generated a $40.1 million and pipeline insight G&A to date. Now obviously, we don't close all of that pipeline, and we're starting small and learning and making sure we get it right, and we're growing the program as we may been before, added other programs in the reseller partners are program. This particular quarter, we'll continue doing that with some of our key partners moving forward. But nothing gives me a peace of mind like having $40 million in pipe in a brand-new program.

componenttext: Hey, Jonathan. It's Andy. So we are seeing, I would say increases our occupancy realization pretty much across the board. I'd say from utilization standpoint, we're kind of on track with our plan moving into the 70s now. And I did mention that we have some wins that call it -- that sign that we undersea cable actually have and flow-through utilization just yet, and actually probably something that's more attractive throughout the customers throughout location. I know we see a lot of demand pointed that. Our Telx location in Santa Clara. And we continue to see tremendous successes be that in [indiscernible] or 56 Marriott and Atlanta or Newark city trifecta. So I can't tell you 1 asset as kind of pulling far, far ahead in terms of percentage it from the orders. So we can a fairly broad-based. And then, your second question was about CapEx. I think it's really just timing-related and you can see from our AFFO reconciliation, if you take those last 3 line items before AFFO, there are some less than $26 million of recurring CapEx and commission to compensation for the quarter. If you multiply that by 4, that's like just 100-ish million dollars of recovering CapEx. And we have affirmed our guidance stable with north of $145 million for the full year. So I think it's just a function of timing and didn't want anyone to think that, that lower number could be truly run rate throughout the rest of the year.

componenttext: And hey Jonathan, to give you a little more color on the West Coast activity. And the number of the properties that we have been looking at end up having an of contiguous space to be attractive to be Digital traditional sales methodology. The larger deals that we see going up against the Santa Clara facility, as well as the Seattle facility as well as the Portland facility that we have simply larger deals, take a little bit longer for us to close. But the cooperation is working exactly as planned.

headline: Digital Realty Trust Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Amy. I'd like to wrap up our call today by recapping our first quarter highlights as outlined here on Page 15. First, we've made significant progress towards extending our global footprint to our top 2 target markets with the acquisition of a l
componenttext: Thank you, Amy. I'd like to wrap up our call today by recapping our first quarter highlights as outlined here on Page 15. First, we've made significant progress towards extending our global footprint to our top 2 target markets with the acquisition of a land parcel in Frankfurt and the signing of an allegory lease and our first project in Japan. We also made headway towards a strategic objective of achieving operating efficiencies to drive accelerating growth in cash flow per share, and we delivered first quarter results well ahead of our own forecast and $0.07 ahead of consensus. We raised guidance by $0.075 at the mid-point on the strength of the beat in the first quarter. And finally, we further strengthened our balance sheet with the successful refinancing of our global credit facilities in January and the completion of our inaugural eurobond offering in early the April. In conclusion, I'd like to say thank you to the entire Digital Realty team, whose hard work and dedication is directly responsible for this consistent execution against our strategic plan. Thank you all for joining us, and we look forward to seeing many of you at NAREIT in June.
